content.raw: At the current state of our testing infrastructure, is making jenkins to hang. See http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/168/ and http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/166/. The test problably leave a second gzserver floating around and the unmounting of the testing chroot is not able to complete the action with that process alive.
content.html: At the current state of our testing infrastructure, is making jenkins to hang. See http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/168/ and http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/166/. The test problably leave a second gzserver floating around and the unmounting of the testing chroot is not able to complete the action with that process alive.

content.raw:
The error messages and warnings are expected: one test tries to load a world that does not exist. This generates an exception that is captured. The other test tries to clone a server with an empty target port which triggers a warning.

The test should kill the cloned gzserver at the end. Does it fail when you run the test locally or is only on Jenkins?
content.html:
The error messages and warnings are expected: one test tries to load a world that does not exist. This generates an exception that is captured. The other test tries to clone a server with an empty target port which triggers a warning.

The test should kill the cloned gzserver at the end. Does it fail when you run the test locally or is only on Jenkins?

content.raw: Seems to work fine in my local machine I will look at what's happening in jenkins.
content.html: Seems to work fine in my local machine I will look at what's happening in jenkins.

content.raw:
I was able to reproduce it in my local machine. It happens in the case when the system does not have a valid killall command available. In linux, killall is part of psmisc. Two ideas:

 * We should fix error detection in our code
 * We should try to get rid of adding dependencies (psmisc) to testing if possible. That would imply to modify code to use plain kill or get the pid and kill from c++ code.
content.html:
I was able to reproduce it in my local machine. It happens in the case when the system does not have a valid killall command available. In linux, killall is part of psmisc. Two ideas:

  • We should fix error detection in our code
  • We should try to get rid of adding dependencies (psmisc) to testing if possible. That would imply to modify code to use plain kill or get the pid and kill from c++ code.

I made a couple of hacks in 8f65fe9 in the branch `cloning_simulation_jrivero`

```
jrivero@nium build $ ./cloner 

Press [ENTER] to clone the current simulation



Press [ENTER] to exit and kill all the servers.
```

There is nothing in gzserver.log and no gzserver process at all. The GUI method worked fine for me.

content.html: I understood that I need to launch gazebo and after run the cloner. If I do that, I don't get the example working. Just using the cloner and gzclient execution in the middle of cloner run make the thing works for me.

content.raw: Wrong comment, you shouldn't run gazebo. Fixed.
content.html: Wrong comment, you shouldn't run gazebo. Fixed.

content.raw:
Moving gzLogInit here will break LogRecord and ParseArgs, both of which use gzerr. 

Thinking on this more, it is probably better to use a time-stamped logfile instead of the "serve-logfile" command line options. Sorry that I lead you down the wrong path.
content.html:
Moving gzLogInit here will break LogRecord and ParseArgs, both of which use gzerr.

Thinking on this more, it is probably better to use a time-stamped logfile instead of the "serve-logfile" command line options. Sorry that I lead you down the wrong path.

content.raw: More thoughts...we should use a uuid instead of a timestamp. We can chat about implementation when you get in to the office.
content.html: More thoughts...we should use a uuid instead of a timestamp. We can chat about implementation when you get in to the office.

content.raw: Done. I modified `Console` class to pass a prefix for the unique directory. So, after running gazebo we'll have a directory ~/.gazebo/server-<UUID> and ~/.gazebo/client-<UUID> . I don't love the idea of creating a lot of directories for informational logging but it's the best solution we have found to support multiple servers running concurrently.
content.html: Done. I modified Console class to pass a prefix for the unique directory. So, after running gazebo we'll have a directory ~/.gazebo/server-<UUID> and ~/.gazebo/client-<UUID> . I don't love the idea of creating a lot of directories for informational logging but it's the best solution we have found to support multiple servers running concurrently.

content.raw: We have been including new features in the migration guide, which is a bad practice. We should start listing only items that break/change API/ABI. All new features will be captured in the ChangeLog.

content.raw:
Use case:

 * Launch gazebo with some parameters, let's say `-e simbody --minimal_comms`
 * Clone
 * New gzserver will not preserve the parameters right?

Preserve all of them blinding would be sometimes dangerous (like keep the record_path for both simulations). But some are probably desired, like physics engine.
content.html:
Use case:

  • Launch gazebo with some parameters, let's say -e simbody --minimal_comms
  • Clone
  • New gzserver will not preserve the parameters right?

Preserve all of them blinding would be sometimes dangerous (like keep the record_path for both simulations). But some are probably desired, like physics engine.

content.raw:
This is a good point and the answer is that the new gzserver will load whatever is saved in the world file. I checked it and when Gazebo is launch with `-e simbody`, the world file saves the next section:


```
#!c++

<physics type='simbody'>
    <max_step_size>0.001</max_step_size>
    <real_time_factor>1</real_time_factor>
    <real_time_update_rate>1000</real_time_update_rate>
    <gravity>0 0 -9.8</gravity>
  </physics>
```

So, simbody is used in the cloned server. However, I don't see anything related with `minimal_comms` in the world file, this will be ignored in the new server.
content.html:
This is a good point and the answer is that the new gzserver will load whatever is saved in the world file. I checked it and when Gazebo is launch with -e simbody, the world file saves the next section:

<physics type='simbody'>
    <max_step_size>0.001</max_step_size>
    <real_time_factor>1</real_time_factor>
    <real_time_update_rate>1000</real_time_update_rate>
    <gravity>0 0 -9.8</gravity>
  </physics>

So, simbody is used in the cloned server. However, I don't see anything related with minimal_comms in the world file, this will be ignored in the new server.

content.raw: Ah ok, so most of the physics engine parameters are being cloned including the engine in use. Probably #1121 would help to be sure about the running configuration.
content.html: Ah ok, so most of the physics engine parameters are being cloned including the engine in use. Probably #1121 would help to be sure about the running configuration.

content.raw: Yes, that would help. If you spawn a PR2 you should see some simbody warnings in your log file.
content.html: Yes, that would help. If you spawn a PR2 you should see some simbody warnings in your log file.

content.raw: Is there an easy way now of knowing which is the log file (directory name) is using a given gzserver/gzclient?
content.html: Is there an easy way now of knowing which is the log file (directory name) is using a given gzserver/gzclient?

content.raw: Add this change in log paths to Migration.md can help to people scripting on top of gazebo log files.
content.html: Add this change in log paths to Migration.md can help to people scripting on top of gazebo log files.

content.raw:
You could always do `ls -t` and sort by date of modification. Other alternative could be use the new overlay mechanism and show the name of the log file used.

Other approach considered was to use an environment variable that, if present, enables the creation of a unique directory containing the log files for this Gazebo instance. If the environment variable is not present the informational log behavior should stay as it is right now.
content.html:
You could always do ls -t and sort by date of modification. Other alternative could be use the new overlay mechanism and show the name of the log file used.

Other approach considered was to use an environment variable that, if present, enables the creation of a unique directory containing the log files for this Gazebo instance. If the environment variable is not present the informational log behavior should stay as it is right now.

content.raw: Update: After discussing this in person, we are going to try a new approach for the informational logs: server-<PORT>.log
content.html: Update: After discussing this in person, we are going to try a new approach for the informational logs: server-<PORT>.log

content.raw: Implemented in 642c4d0.
content.html: Implemented in 642c4d0.

content.raw:
Server log message changed in a4ace8a.

The information about the new server is sent to the client using a message. For now, the client writes this information in its log. Ideally, we should write a new line in the status bar (that we haven't implemented yet). How about if we put this suggestion on hold until we have the status bar? Then, we can create a new topic for sending notifications that will be displayed in the status bar.
content.html:
Server log message changed in a4ace8a.

The information about the new server is sent to the client using a message. For now, the client writes this information in its log. Ideally, we should write a new line in the status bar (that we haven't implemented yet). How about if we put this suggestion on hold until we have the status bar? Then, we can create a new topic for sending notifications that will be displayed in the status bar.
